title: Get your heart pumping on New Zealand's North Island
text:
July 6, 2015 Mariusz Prusaczyk , Fotolia 
AHIPARA, New Zealand — New Zealand is renowned for its devotion to adventurous and (let’s be honest) often made-up sports. 
The birthplace of commercial bungee jumping, it also offers such activities as black water rafting (traversing icy underground streams with an inner tube), land yachting (think windsurfing, but on the beach with a four-wheeled cart) and Zorbing (rolling down a hill in a human hamster ball). 
While the country’s mountainous South Island (and especially Queenstown) gets much of the attention from active travellers, a recent visit focused on the North Island – its milder climate is much more appealing to a winter-weary Canadian. Also now known as Te Ika-a-Maui – “the fish of Maui,” the Maori name that recently received an official stamp of approval in the spirit of Haida Gwaii – the North Island offers a rich diversity of landscapes, from soft ocean beaches to rocky mountain peaks. Most importantly, boredom isn’t an option. 
Sandboarding – zooming down dunes on a foam boogie board – is one way to guarantee that. Ahipara , on the west coast of Northland, the country’s northernmost region, is a fantastic place to start. The two-restaurant, no-ATM town sits at the foot of the famous Ninety Mile Beach, a wide, flat, packed-sand expanse that’s also technically a road (and about 90 km long). It’s a prime spot for other active adventures such as surfing, land yachting, quad biking, horse trekking and kayaking. It’s also just 15 minutes from Kaitaia , launch point for numerous bus tours to Cape Reinga , New Zealand’s northernmost accessible point. 
The focus on fresh air and adventure continues heading south from Ahipara. At the almost 30-year-old Goat Island Marine Reserve , a popular diving and snorkelling spot about an hour north of Auckland , a wetsuit, mask and flippers are all that’s needed to glide across an underwater wonderland, spotting seaweed forests, plenty of huge fish and manta rays. 
Mount Maunganui , a treasured beach getaway for generations of Kiwis, offers a hike up to the summit of Mauao , the 232-metre extinct volcano that’s the town’s focal point. Verdant pathways are filled with native birdsong and panoramic views of the Pacific and of Tauranga Harbour. The town made headlines a few years ago when container ship MV Rena crashed on a nearby reef and spilled oil and debris on the shore; now, the bulk of the wreck has been removed and the kilometres-long stretch of white-sand beach is clean again. It’s still a playground for surfers, kayakers, kiteboarders and paddleboarders; not to mention the kids competing in the national surf life-saving championships. 
Rotorua is one of the country’s top tourist destinations, due to its status as a Maori cultural centre and hyperbole-inducing natural environment. It’s an active geothermal area complete with geysers, steaming sulphuric vents, bubbling mud pools and a plethora of natural hot springs that made it a spa destination even back in the 19th century. 
But it’s Rotorua’s year-round mountain biking scene that’s been grabbing headlines and luring visitors of late. Wade Garmson, guide with Multi-Day Adventures , leads visitors on a tour of the Redwoods Whakarewarewa Forest , which contains 130 kilometres of dedicated bike trails. New Zealand’s mountain biking trails are graded from one to six – that is, easy to insane. Back in town, pedal pushers recover first with pizza and local craft beer at Brew, then with a twilight soak in the mineral-rich lakeside hot pools at the Polynesian Spa. 
After two days of riding, Volcanic Hills Winery at Skyline is a welcome spot for a celebratory tasting. As winemaker Sean Beer runs through a crash course on Kiwi wine-growing regions, some in attendance are only half listening. 
They have more adventures in mind. 
IF YOU GO 
Air New Zealand flies direct from Vancouver to Auckland five days a week (daily from mid-December to mid-January), with frequent connections to Tauranga, Rotorua and other cities. 
Ahipara Adventure Centre rents a full range of gear: boogie boards, surfboards, wetsuits, quad bikes, land yachts, kayaks and more. Or traverse Ninety Mile Beach on horseback with Ahipara Horse Treks ; tours start at $65 per person. Access to Goat Island Marine Reserve is free; rent wetsuits and snorkelling gear at nearby Octopus Hideaway . Rotorua-based Multi-Day Adventures arranges small-scale adventure tours across New Zealand, covering activities including mountain biking, whitewater rafting, kayaking, hiking and rock climbing. For those on a tight schedule, their popular Rotorua Adventure Day ($360 per person) begins with two to three hours of mountain biking followed by a rafting adventure that includes a seven-metre waterfall drop, then finishes with a lake kayak to hot pools accessible only by boat. 
Rent bikes on-site at the Redwoods Whakarewarewa Forest or Skyline Rotorua with Mountain Bike Rotorua , who also offer guided tours and bike mechanical support. © Copyright (c) Postmedia Network Inc. E-mail this Article
